title: API Fuzzing errors when HAR file contains UTF-8 BOM
description:
### Problem

API Fuzzing validates several json file types such as HAR. When the HAR file contains a UTF-8 BOM character, decoding fails in worker-entry. UTF-8 BOM character was included in the Fiddler HAR export.

```
Error, error occurred trying to read `graphql.har` file: Unexpected UTF-8 BOM (decode using utf-8-sig): line 1 column 1 (char 0)
```

Example job: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/demos/api-fuzzing/graphql-api-fuzzing-example/-/jobs/1037589006

### Proposal

1. [x] Add integration test with UTF-8 BOM
   1. [x] HAR
   1. [x] Postman Collection
   1. [x] OpenApi Specification
   1. [x] Overrides json
1. [x] Update encoding method used in python code. 
   ```
   r.encoding='utf-8-sig'
   data = json.loads(r.text)
   ```
1. [x] Release new container

title: CWE-611 XML External Entity (XXE) for DAST API
description:
### Problem

API Security (Peach API) scanner doesn't support CWE-611 XXE. This is a gap between API Security and ZAP.

### Proposal

Links: 
 - [OWASP XXE](https://owasp.org/www-community/vulnerabilities/XML_External_Entity_(XXE)_Processing)
 - [ZAP](https://www.zaproxy.org/docs/alerts/90023/)

1. [x] Add XXE vulnerability to flask target
   - Extend an existing POST operation
     - detect `application/xml` content-type
     - parse XML into expected dict
     - return json
     - make sure xml library has remote entities enabled
1. [x] Add support for checks that require callbacks
   - New service `CheckCallbackService` is glue between controller and check
     - Service keeps state (singleton)
     - Controller takes it in constructor
     - Callbacks are multi-use (can be called more than once)
     - Registered callbacks should be deregistered via the Service
     - service will return a URL for the registered callback
       - URL format: http://apifuzzer/api/checkcallback/GUID
   - We add a new controller called `CheckCallbackController`.
     - Controller takes service in constructor
     - Only support GET requests
   - Check can register a callback providing a delegate
     - only support GET requests
     - delegate provides result content + status code
       - Parameters: Controller instance (?? Can we access needed information, such as request)
       - Return: ContentResult
   - Check can then use returned URLs
1. [x] Add the document as a type of parameter for JSON and XML.
   - Add a new `ParameterType` of `Document`
   ```
	[Flags]
	public enum ParameterType
	{
		None     = 0,
		Array    = 1 << 0,
		Boolean  = 1 << 1,
		Integer  = 1 << 2,
		Null     = 1 << 3,
		Number   = 1 << 4,
		Object   = 1 << 5,
		String   = 1 << 6,
		File     = 1 << 7,
		Document = 1 << 8
	}
   ```
   - For XmlBody, update the `Elements` property to return a `Document` parameter
     - In the constructor create a `Document` String DataElement that contains the `xml` argument as it's content
     - In `Elements` property, yield the document parameter first.
     - In WriteTo - Check to see if the document parameter has been modified, if so return it's value
   - For JsonBody
     - In the constructor create a `Document` String DataElement that contains the `json` argument as it's content/value
     - In `Elements` property yield the document parameter first.
     - In WriteTo - Check to see if the document parameter has been modified, if so return it's value
   - Add tests :)
1. [x] Create new check
    1. [x] XXE Remote File Inclusion Attack
    - Config Options: 
      - Enabled Flag
      - Callback Host
    - Test (Total of test is 1)
      - Apply to
        - Request content type like `xml` 
        - Parameter type `Document`. (using new implementation for parameter type `Document`) 
      - Register callback (using new CheckCallbackService), and get callback url.
      - Computes new request content using the template (attack header+attack body), and callback url.
      - Assertion
        - Implement Custom Callback assertion. It will verify registered callback has been executed. 
    1. [x] XXE Local File Reflection Attack
      - Config Options: 
        - Enabled Flag
        - Local File Targets. List of possible files to be targeted (e.g. `"file:///etc/passwd"`, `"file:///c:/Windows/system.ini"`, `"file:///d:/Windows/system.ini"`)
        - Attack Strength: Indicates how many individual elements should be used for attempting the attack.
      - Test (Total is:  1 Test placing all elements by Count(local File Targets) + Number of Test base on (Attack Strength)). NOTE: For the first element, it attempts all the local file targets before moving to the next element, this counts as an iteration for the attack strength.
        - Apply to
          - Request content type like `xml` 
          - Parameter type `Document`. (using new implementation for parameter type `Document`) (TBD or `String`, requires changing values thus `String` should be enough, but also injects the DTD section.)
        - ​On the first test, replace all element values.
          - Compute the Content of the Request for each local file target use template for DTD.
      ​  - On the remaining tests, just replace one element value with the attack entity and inject DTD. 
          - Compute the Content of the Request for each local file target use template for DTD.
      - Assertion
          - Use `LogAnalysisAssertion` to review logs. It might need to create new entries/category (look or filename, file content)
          - Use `ResponseAnalysisAssertionConfig` to review response. It might need to create new entries/category   (look or filename, file content)   
    1. [x] XXE Local File Inclusion Attack
      - Config Options: 
        - Enabled Flag
        - Local File Targets. List of possible files to be targeted (e.g. `"file:///etc/passwd"`, `"file:///c:/Windows/system.ini"`, `"file:///d:/Windows/system.ini"`)
      - Test (Count (Local File Targets))
        - Apply to
          - Request content type like `xml` 
          - Parameter type `Document`. (using new implementation for parameter type `Document`) 
        - For each local file target
          - Compute attack requests using a template for Attack Header, Attack body, and current local file target
      - Assertion
          - Use `LogAnalysisAssertion` to review logs. It might need to create new entries/category (look or filename, file content)
          - Use `ResponseAnalysisAssertionConfig` to review response. It might need to create new entries/category   (look or filename, file content)
1. [x] Add XXE Check to:
    1. [x] API DAST project
    1. [x] API FUZZ project
1. [x] Meta data tech writer review
1. [x] Unit tests
1. [x] Integration tests
1. [x] E2E Tests
1. [x] Java benchmark passe
1. [x] Update the [master configuration file in the dast project](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/dast/-/blob/master/config/gitlab-dast-api-config.yml). Should end up matching the dast config from SDK/configs.
1. [x] Publish a new container

title: CWE-78 OS Command Injection for DAST API
description:
### Problem

API Security (Peach API) scanner doesn't support CWE-78 OS Command Injection vulnerabilities. This is a gap between API Security and ZAP.

### Proposal

The Command Injection Check will perform both standard and blind injections. Standard injections are paired with a regex pattern to check the response body with. For blind injections, a new blind assertion will be used. Timings for standard injections will be used to find a baseline on the modified requests.

Check specification: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/dast-cwe-checks/-/blob/main/78/78.1.yaml

Technology Supported:

- Unix
- Windows
- PowerShell

Check Configuration:

- Commands for both standard and blind injections
- Patterns for standard injections
- Number of injections to perform
- List of injections

1. [x] Create new assertion for blind injections

title: F/u/f !51003: Improve the trial status popover copy
description:
This is a follow-up improvement to #288015 & !51003.

Start of the first thread of conversation: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/288015#note_506270725

The second thread: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/288015#note_508735745

And the third thread: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/288015#note_510491132

## Desired Changes

- [x] Change the popover title to match the widget title: “You’ve got `x` day(s) remaining on GitLab Ultimate (Formerly Gold)!”
- [x] Change the popover content to read:
   > Your trial ends on `March 2`. We hope you’re enjoying the features of GitLab Ultimate (Formerly Gold). To keep those features after your trial ends, you’ll need to buy a subscription. (You can also choose GitLab Premium (Formerly Silver) if it meets your needs.)
   - [x] Change the date format from `YYYY-MM-DD` to `mmm d` (or whatever the actual syntax is to get the full month)
- [-] Double check that we want to use the actual plan name from the database rather than a hard-coded version
  - From the database: “Ultimate (Formerly Gold)” & “Premium (Formerly Silver)”
    - Risk: the titles are currently rather long since they incorporate the former names
  - Hard-coded: “Ultimate” & “Premium” (or whatever we want, really)
    - Risk: when the titles changes, we may have to make a code change
  - Doesn’t matter much to me. We’re already passing the values from the database in, let’s just keep using those for now (I think they got updated to their normal versions, anyway).

title: Scaffold work to implement combined menu
description:
The top-navigation change will be a quite impactful one, so we should be smart about the rollout of the initial work.
In this case we aim for the following:

- [ ] Feature Flag that allows to render a different version of the top navigation
- [ ] Aim for the FF to be enabled only on a per-user basis till we have everything in that's needed
- [ ] Think about an option where people within GitLab can self optin and optout of the feature flag, so they won't be blocked by this if something goes wrong.
- [ ] Define if there are any other issues needed before kicking off implementations based on the parent epic

### Availability and Testing

Since there is a plan to enable this in stages and allow opting in, we should create some automation with the ff enabled state in addition to the default. Please include a SET in MR reviews to keep them updated on the progress. At a later date we might need to adjust our existing tests if ff enabled globally.

title: Increase specificity of StandardContext environment
description:
Currently in [`standard_context.rb`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/lib/gitlab/tracking/standard_context.rb), we have three possible environments:

```ruby
      def environment
        return 'production' if Gitlab.com_and_canary?

        return 'staging' if Gitlab.staging?

        'development'
      end

```

We need to account for a couple of new cases:
- Self-managed customer instances
- dev.gitlab.org

title: GraphQL updates to remove WIP in favor of Draft
description:
https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/32692 introduced the `draft` term in order to replace `WIP`. However, the API still uses the term as part of the API, as @aqualls noted in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/231502 for documentation work.

The deprecation process for GraphQL (https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/graphql/#deprecation-process) says a 6-month timeline is required between change and removal, but I'm not sure if that clock started with https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/32692 or if it starts with this issue landing.

Users have [commented on API inconsistency](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/32692#note_457051366) and I am unsure if that comment has been addressed.

I know more scoping work is undoubtedly needed, so I'm passing this issue over to @m_gill and cc'ing @phikai.

## Identified pages with problems

- `doc/user/project/quick_actions.md` - was the `/wip` quick action updated? (This may need to be a separate issue)
- `doc/development/api_graphql_styleguide.md` - contains code examples that discuss WIP-related mutations. This doc should be updated by an engineer; your technical writer (Amy) can review it afterward
- `doc/api/graphql/reference/index.md` - contains two sections of work: the definitions (which Amy is comfortable modifying) and the API itself. Those changes should originate from an engineer, not a TW.

As an aside, review https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/32692#note_457051366 to see if bugs still need to be filed?

## Related issues

- Related to https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/32692 (Rename WIP merge requests to Draft)
- Related to https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/231502 (Replace all instances of "WIP" to "draft" in GitLab docs)

title: FE: Change the status of a specific Alert
description:
<!--
Implementation issues are used break-up a large piece of work into small, discrete tasks that can
move independently through the build workflow steps. They're typically used to populate a Feature
Epic. Once created, an implementation issue is usually refined in order to populate and review the
implementation plan and weight.
Example workflow: https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/development/threat-management/planning/diagram.html#plan
-->

## Why are we doing this work
<!--
A brief explanation of the why, not the what or how. Assume the reader doesn't know the
background and won't have time to dig-up information from comment threads.
-->

In order to triage alerts, a security operations engineer or a security analyst must be able to change the status of an Alert.

With the addition of https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/51417 our Alerts Dashboard & Alert Details page will have the following functionality: 
* create the details page which can be shared so users can go straight to an alert,
* allow for todos to be created,
* allow incidents to be created,
* let alerts be assigned

Changing the alert status on the details page was not be included as there was extra work that needed to be done around changing the statuses to match the threat monitoring alert list page (i.e. the operations page uses different alerts than threat monitoring and we mapped them).

Allowing for the alert status to be changed in the details page is my next task.

title: Add retry as a migration option to Elasticsearch migrations
description:
<!-- This template is a great use for issues that are feature::additions or technical tasks for larger issues.-->

### Proposal 

Currently migrations can be built with retry logic but it is added manually. We should build an automated retry feature as a new [ee/app/workers/concerns/elastic/migration_options.rb](Elastic::MigrationOptions). The feature could have a default `MAX_RETRIES` and also have a configurable `max_retries` if someone wishes to change it. This would allow developers to write migrations and not worry that they will run forever if an issue is encountered.

<!-- Use this section to explain the feature and how it will work. It can be helpful to add technical details, design proposals, and links to related epics or issues. -->

You can also reference the Feature Proposal Template (https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/.gitlab/issue_templates/Feature%20proposal.md) for additional details to consider adding to this issue. Additionally, as a data oriented organization, when your feature exits planning breakdown, consider adding the `What does success look like, and how can we measure that?` section.



-->

title: FE: Disable On-Demand Scan editing for profiles defined in Scan Policies

title: Add gemnasium testdata directory to list of ignored paths
description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "bug" label:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=regression
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=bug

and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.
--->

### Summary

Dependency Scanning reports a vulnerability in the `gemnasium` project when scanning the `scanner/testdata` folder and finds vulnerabilities (as intended). This folder should be ignored when scanning the project.

### Steps to reproduce

Run dependency scanning on the `gemnasium` project.

### Example Project

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium

title: Add aggregate counts for epic boards related user driven events
description:
> This is the implementation issue that came out of https://gitlab.com/gitlab-data/analytics/-/issues/5280


## Goal

Track user interactions with **Epic Boards** within the [usage ping] so that we can calculate Monthly Active Users (MAU) for Plan. It is important that we have an accurate reflect of MAU as it is one of the primary metrics that GitLab leadership uses to [make informed investment decisions](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product/investment/) across the product.

## Product Planning MAU Definition

[The sum of all unique users that took an action within an epic over a given period of time.]

## Proposal

Implement a counter in the [usage ping] that aggregates the total count of unique users that took an action on an epic.

## Board Events To Aggregate In [Usage Ping]

**Note:** These counters must be able to **split by Issue Board and Epic Board** and eventually Issue Type.

* = Immediately implement with roll out

| Action | Description | Added To Counter | Assignee |
|--------|-------------|------------------|----------|
| board_created * |Board created | https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/60357  | jprovaznik |
| board_viewed * |Board viewed |  https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/60357 | jprovaznik |
| board_swimlane_changed * | Changed the swimlane of the board | |   |
| board_title_changed  | Changed the title of the board | https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/60357 | jprovaznik |
| board_swimlane_edited | Changed the swimlane of the board | |   |

### Snowplow events

| Category | Label | Action | Property | Value | Added |
|----------|-------|--------|----------|-------|-------|
| Rails page attribute | board_switcher | click_dropdown | | | |
| Rails page attribute | toggle | show_labels | [off, on] | | Yes |
| Rails page attribute | edit_board | click_button | | | |
| Rails page attribute | create_list | click_button | | | |
| Rails page attribute | toggle_list | click_toggle_button | [open, closed] | | |
| Rails page attribute | right_sidebar | click_card | | | |
| Rails page attribute | board | drag_card | | | |
| Rails page attribute | list_settings | click_button | | | |
| Rails page attribute | remove_list | click_button | | | |


### Related issues for reference

[Add aggregate counts for epic related user driven events issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/292253)

title: Cleanup possible dead code from old Run Pipeline form
Improve performance of Pipeline table page by reducing amount of DOM elements
description:
### Description

We should keep an eye on the amount of DOM nodes we render in the table, as they may impact our performance.

We are rendering a whooping 5K DOM nodes in the pipelines table page, while only ~700 are shown before we render the table:

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/pipelines

![Screen_Shot_2021-02-16_at_6.23.18_PM](/uploads/98ee782c3c49265f7b15193903a21224/Screen_Shot_2021-02-16_at_6.23.18_PM.png)

Lighthouse asks to keep under 1500, which I think it's reasonable for the amount of information we show on the page, more at: https://web.dev/dom-size/#how-the-lighthouse-dom-size-audit-fails

### Proposal

Clean up child components that `app/assets/javascripts/pipelines/components/pipelines_list/pipelines_table.vue` uses. Clean up any unnecessary DOM elements with the goal of reducing loaded DOM elements under `1500`

title: Jira connect /api/:version/repos/:namespace/:project/events API route has SQL n + 1 issues
description:
Discovered as part of https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/gl-infra/scalability/-/issues/865

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The `/api/:version/repos/:namespace/:project/events` endpoint, used for JIRA connect, has SQL n+1 problems, resulting sometimes in more than 1000 SQL queries per request.

https://log.gprd.gitlab.net/goto/7900e06c7d8ed9429975b8d8ea230ed2	

	
![image](/uploads/b5f21bcecc7e4aa4c5abcde16cc9713e/image.png)

title: Rename InstanceStatistics workers as UsageTrend workers
description:
Eliminate the old, renamed workers from Gitlab and omnibus:

- analytics_instance_statistics_count_job_trigger_worker
- analytics_usage_trends_count_job_trigger_worker

The following discussion from !54153 should be addressed:

- [ ] @pshutsin started a [discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/54153#note_509991089):  (+4 comments)

    > I think we need backwards compatibility here too since there can be jobs scheduled with old name. I think we should keep old class name available until next major release. https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/sidekiq_style_guide.html#removing-workers

title: Remove nil values from snippets blobs
Re-enable etag caching for Notes
description:
Etag caching was disabled for the notes endpoint in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/52765, leading to slowdowns that have been reported in multiple places including:

* https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/52765#note_510821903
* https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/209784

There is also some evidence that these uncached requests are hitting the Postgres primary which is already under a great deal of pressure https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/gl-infra/scalability/-/issues/865

![image](/uploads/c4c9c837dd9efed7c1765e8d410d11a7/image.png)

https://thanos-query.ops.gitlab.net/graph?g0.range_input=8w&g0.max_source_resolution=0s&g0.expr=controller_action%3Agitlab_sql_duration_seconds_sum%3Arate1m%7Bcontroller%3D%22Projects%3A%3ANotesController%22%2Cenvironment%3D%22gprd%22%2Cstage%3D%22main%22%2Ctype%3D%22web%22%7D&g0.tab=0

I suggest we undo this change, urgently.

cc @brentnewton @marin @dskim_gitlab

title: Simplify vulnerability report component structure (dashboard components)
description:
There are 3 types of vulnerability reports: **project** level, **group** level, and **instance** level:

|Project level|Group level|Instance level|
|-|-|-|
|![ksnip_20210114-020743](/uploads/13e08e4345e4e4cdcbe17cb589279c06/ksnip_20210114-020743.png)|![ksnip_20210114-020829](/uploads/e4fb83a023c482745e97bb9a7775fe72/ksnip_20210114-020829.png)|![ksnip_20210114-021043](/uploads/c8dc5ab42ec5764f3f98e64c2c4aca5e/ksnip_20210114-021043.png)|

Currently, each report uses a specific root-level dashboard component, a specific component that fetches vulnerability data and sets up some properties, and finally a common vulnerability list component used by all 3:

||
|-|
|![test__1_](/uploads/0aa6c65d7e4872e50d6d1f0026dbe655/test__1_.png)|

There's a lot of overlap between the files in the top two layers. Because these dashboards look and behave almost exactly the same and differ only in what level of vulnerabilities are shown, we should combine them into one common component and use `props` to configure what is shown. Otherwise, any work that needs to be done in one of the components will need to be duplicated across the other two, for example [this MR where the same `watch()` block needed to be copied 3 times](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/53934#note_506590184).

## Implementation plan

- [x] Combine the 3 dashboard components into one common component.
- [x] Combine the 3 setup components into one common component.
- [ ] If possible, combine the common dashboard component into the common setup component.
- [ ] If possible, combine everything into `vulnerability_list.vue`.

Note that it may be possible to merge all 6 components in the top two layers into the already-existing `vulnerability_list.vue` component, then use `props` to pass in the correct GraphQL query and show/hide the counts.

title: Enforce JSON schema validation for generic security report - FE
description:
<!--
Implementation issues are used break-up a large piece of work into small, discrete tasks that can
move independently through the build workflow steps. They're typically used to populate a Feature
Epic. Once created, an implementation issue is usually refined in order to populate and review the
implementation plan and weight.
Example workflow: https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/development/threat-management/planning/diagram.html#plan
-->

## Why are we doing this work
<!--
A brief explanation of the why, not the what or how. Assume the reader doesn't know the
background and won't have time to dig-up information from comment threads.
-->

Display error(s) to customers on the Pipeline Security Report when security report schema does not pass validation.

From @andyvolpe in [this discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/284062#note_504209120): 
> **For the MVC**, add an alert outside of and above the scan details section of the security tab (/pipeline/00000000/security). Since the scan details can be expanded and collapsed, we'd risk the user missing the alert if we nested it with that information. I'll upload a quick mock into the design section of this issue.

## Relevant links

Design mocks: 
* https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/284062/designs/a_01-pipeline-schema-error.png
* https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/284062/designs/a_02-pipeline-schema-error_multiple-in-one-job.png

<!--
Information that the developer might need to refer to when implementing the issue.

- [Design Issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/<id>)
  - [Design 1](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/<id>/designs/<image>.png)
  - [Design 2](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/<id>/designs/<image>.png)
- [Similar implementation](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/<id>)
-->


## Non-functional requirements
<!--
Add details for required items and delete others.
-->

- [ ] Documentation:
- [ ] Feature flag:
- [ ] Performance:
- [ ] Testing:


## Implementation plan
<!--
Steps and the parts of the code that will need to get updated. The plan can also
call-out responsibilities for other team members or teams.
-->

- [ ] ~frontend 
  - [x] Update `ee/app/assets/javascripts/security_dashboard/graphql/queries/pipeline_security_report_summary.query.graphql` to include the `name` and `error` field for each scan (see example query below)
  - [x] Add logic to `ee/app/assets/javascripts/security_dashboard/components/pipeline_security_dashboard.vue`
   - [x] If there are any errors then display the alert
   - [x] For each scanner with an error add an expandable section (using `GlAccordion` and `GlAccordionItem`)
   - [x] Add an error count to each section header
   - [x] Show all errors within each section
   - [ ] Add specs

### Example Query

```graphql
{
  project(fullPath: $fullPath) {
    name
    pipeline(iid: $iid) {
      securityReportSummary {
        sast {
          vulnerabilitiesCount
          scans {
            nodes {
              name
              errors
            }
          }
        }
      }
    }
  }
}

```

### Note

The GraphQL query is currently behind a feature flag. To enable it run

```bash
echo "Feature.enable(:pipeline_security_dashboard_graphql)" | rails c
```

### Verification steps

- Create blank project on GitLab.com
- Add `.gitlab-ci.yml` file with the following content;

    ```yml
    .test-sast:
      variables:
        VALIDATE_SCHEMA: "true"
      artifacts:
        reports:
          sast: "${CI_JOB_NAME}.json"
      script:
        - echo "$REPORT_CONTENT" > "${CI_JOB_NAME}.json"

    test-sast-1:
      extends: .test-sast
      variables:
        REPORT_CONTENT: '{"foo": "BAR"}'

    test-sast-2:
      extends: .test-sast
      variables:
        REPORT_CONTENT: '{"version": "14.0.0", "vulnerabilities": []}'

    dast:
      script:
        - wget -O "${CI_JOB_NAME}.json" https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/dast/-/raw/main/test/end-to-end/expect/test_baseline_api_scan.json
      artifacts:
        reports:
          dast: "${CI_JOB_NAME}.json"
    ```
- Verify that you can see the schema errors related to `test-sast-1` build.

~"group::" ~"Category:" ~"GitLab Ultimate"
-->

Other settings you might want to include when creating the issue.

-->

title: Cascading Settings - Make POC Production Ready
description:
<!-- This issue template can be used a great starting point for feature requests. The last section "Release notes" can be used as a summary of the feature and is also required if you want to have your release post blog MR auto generated using the release post item generator:  https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/blog/release-posts/#release-post-item-generator. The remaining sections are the backbone for every feature in GitLab. -->

### Release notes 

<!-- What is the problem and solution you're proposing? This content sets the overall vision for the feature and serves as the release notes that will populate in various places, including the [release post blog](https://about.gitlab.com/releases/categories/releases/) and [Gitlab project releases](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/releases). " -->

### Problem to solve 

In issue https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/291082 we implemented a POC for cascading settings from a group to all subgroups below it. This issue will track the work needed to make this feature production-ready. The first setting we will support is delayed project deletion. 

### Proposal 

Complete hardening of the feature for GA release

See https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/51498 for ~backend POC. The code is not quite production ready. 

- Migrations were messy and need to be updated after https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/53916 is merged. 
- Needs tests.
- Needs developer documentation on using `lockable_attrs` and the associated database migrations (lock column, can be null, etc). 
- Document `CascadingNamespaceAttribute` so the code is clear to future developers. Since it's a bit of meta-programming it can be difficult to understand at first.

title: Geo Self Service - Replicable Data Types
description:
## What/Why With the new Geo Status UI: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/53090 we now expose the Data Type of the replicable to the user. However, currently the `replicator_class` doesn't have knowledge of if it is a `Git` or `File` replicable. Having this information to provide to the UI would be incredibly helpful. ## Proposal Add a method to the `replicator_class` (`replicator.rb`) that returns whether it is `repository` or `blob`.
Add a method to the `replicator_class` (`replicactor.rb`) that returns its user friendly title `Git` or `File`. **Examples** ```rb def self.data_type # Logic for Data Type end ``` ```rb def self.data_type_title # Logic for Data Type Title end ``` cc/ @geo-team

title: Move aggregated metrics YAML configs into `config` directory
description:
## Background

Initially aggregated metrics YAML definitions was placed in [`lib/gitlab/usage_data_counters/aggregated_metrics/`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/lib/gitlab/usage_data_counters/aggregated_metrics/), because first iteration of aggregated metric feature started as part of the [`HLLRedisCounter`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/lib/gitlab/usage_data_counters/hll_redis_counter.rb) which were relaying on YAML configs at [`lib/gitlab/usage_data_counters/known_events/`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/lib/gitlab/usage_data_counters/known_events/), and such location seemed to be unified with the rest of the implementation. However right now it seems that this is no longer valid case.

Additional historical context: 
https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/52334 
I would add new issue to change location of all aggregated metric configs along with corresponding test files

## Goal

Move aggregated metric YAML definitions into more appropriate place withing `config` directory and move corresponding test files [`spec/lib/gitlab/usage_data_counters/`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/lib/gitlab/usage_data_counters)

title: Not all security scans are enabled by Auto DevOps
description:
### Summary

In a project which has Auto DevOps enabled, the Security Configuration page claims that:

> All security scans are enabled because Auto DevOps is enabled on this project

when in fact the table immediately below shows that _not_ all security scans are enabled.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Create a new project
1. Enable Auto DevOps for the project
1. (May not be necessary?) Run a CI pipeline on the default branch
1. Visit the project's Security Configuration page

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

_Either_ it's that not all security scans are enabled by Auto DevOps, when they should, _or_ it's that the language in the Security Configuration page is misleading/incorrect.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

We should be consistent when saying what's enabled via Auto DevOps by changing the wording `All security scans` to `Several security scans`

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

![ado_issues](/uploads/28787ac2506b4b3b024815a264e86874/ado_issues.png)

### Possible fixes

Either:
- Enable all security scans when Auto DevOps is enabled; _or_
- Change the language/wording on the Security Configuration page

title: Imported group membership not reflected in child project members API
description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "bug" label:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=regression
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=bug

and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.
--->

### Summary

1. Create a group and a subgroup, let's say `group1` and `group1/group2`
2. Import another group, let's say `imported-group`, into either of them
3. Create a project under `group1/group2`, let's say `project`
4. Check membership API for `project` members (`projectID/members/all`). This should list all project members including inherited from parent groups
5. Observe that members of `imported-group` are missing from the API. This happens both with importing the group into `group1` and `group1/group2`

### Steps to reproduce

See above

### Example Project

<!-- If possible, please create an example project here on GitLab.com that exhibits the problematic 
behavior, and link to it here in the bug report. If you are using an older version of GitLab, this 
will also determine whether the bug is fixed in a more recent version. -->

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

Members from groups imported into parent groups in the project don't show up in the members API endpoint of the project. The membership itself works, as the imported members have permissions to do everything in the web UI. It's just an API problem.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

When listing `members/all`, *all* members including ones from the imported groups are listed

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

<!-- Paste any relevant logs - please use code blocks (```) to format console output, logs, and code
 as it's tough to read otherwise. -->

### Output of checks

This bug happens on GitLab.com

### Possible fixes

@leopardm was helping with debugging the problem. Copying his full comment over:

>  I tried to see if a workaround to this could be a GraphQL query. I set up this structure:
> 
>     abc123
>         test-group (1 member)
>             shared with group_of_people
>             test-project
>                 shared with another_group_of_people
>     group_of_people (6 members)
>     another_group_of_people (1 member)
> 
> I tried this query:
> 
> ```
> query {
> 	project(fullPath: "abc123/test-group/test-project") {
>     fullPath,
>     projectMembers(relations:[INVITED_GROUPS, DIRECT, INHERITED, DESCENDANTS]){
>       nodes{
>         id,
>         user{
>           name,
>           publicEmail,
>           ...
>         }
>       }
>     }
>   }
> }
> ```
> 
> And was able to retrieve all the members of the project, including those belonging to the directly invited groups. However, it still did not include any members inherited into test-group. Also, it appears the INVITED_GROUPS relation is not present when using GraphQL to query a group and all of its members.
> 
> It looks like the lack of a concept of INVITED_GROUPS at the group level is causing this problem, in both the REST API and GraphQL API

title: Improve diffs app usage of requestIdleCallback
description:
## Important

* For the context of this effort, please see: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/323616
* Until we can bring the TBT metric within acceptable ranges, that issue will stay open.
* This issue tracks only the delivery of this solution/approach

## Summary

In the diffs app we use `requestIdleCallback` to start the render queue for the diffs themselves. This is fine and allows us to wait until the browser is ready before doing anything. However, we should look at using the `IdleDeadline` passed in to determine how many diffs we can actually render in the idling time.

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/25c1fcfc6c58606789e78a96538173e7a5492e8f/app/assets/javascripts/diffs/components/app.vue#L352

<!--
Please briefly describe what part of the code base needs to be refactored.
-->

## Improvements

Look into using the `IdleDeadline` parameter passed into the `requestIdleCallback` callback method.

We should also look at other usages in the diffs app and see if we can improve them.

We could also look at adding this into rendering the diff lines themselves.

<!--
Explain the benefits of refactoring this code.
See also https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/values/index.html#say-why-not-just-what
-->

## Risks

We should in theory improve the blocking time by only rendering what we know we can render. However, doing this probably means the total rendering time will increase as we wait for the browser to go idle before doing any rendering work.

This will probably be more visible when rendering diff lines.

Please list features that can break because of this refactoring and how you intend to solve that.
-->

-->

title: Rails' jobs (i.e. jobs extending from `.rails-cache`) cache wasn't updated between 2021-01-27 and 2021-02-13, leading to an increase in duration
description:
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/52693 introduced a new cache for Rails' jobs (i.e. jobs extending from `.rails-cache`) that don't need the `.go/pkg/mod/` folder
- In the Version 2 of the MR (on 2021-01-27), the cache was populated: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/52693/diffs?diff_id=138948734#f524b8634382f96f339588eeef428dc36ca401b5_27_34 => https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/jobs/990591107#L506
- The MR was merged on 2021-02-02, and the Rails' jobs were taking advantage of the cache: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/jobs/1001109320#L43
- **The MR didn't set the cache policy to `push` for the `update-rails-cache` job, leading to a stale cache over time...**
- On 2021-02-04, the cache becoming stale, `bundle install` would take 90 seconds to finish: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/jobs/1009349692#L66 (instead of 14 seconds normally: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/jobs/1001109320#L65)
- On 2021-02-11 (approximately two weeks after it was first populated), [the cache wasn't there anymore](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/jobs/1022506160#L45), leading to `bundle install` taking between 500 and 600 seconds (8 to 10 minutes): https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/jobs/1022506160#L66
- On 2021-02-15, I've opened https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/54249 to fix the cache policy for the `update-rails-cache` job. The MR includes `[UPDATE CACHE]` so the cache was re-populated
- Soon after, jobs started to take advantage of the cache again: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/jobs/1031425609#L44, finishing 10 minutes faster :sweat_smile: 

We should also think about adding an automatic detection of such regressions.

Related to https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/300192.

title: Refactor HistoricalData#max_historical_user_count
description:
In [a review comment](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/53878#note_507737425) for fixing the incorrect seat overage calculation, a suggestion to refactor the method `HistoricalData#max_historical_user_count` came up. 

All calls for the method without parameters were removed so they can be made compulsory. Since this will remove the fallback logic within the method the `license` parameter can be removed as well. The fallback logic was also closely related to license anyway and should be done within the `License` model.

title: Create a GraphQL resolver that returns a list of available branches for a project
description:
### Problem to solve 

In order to create a branch switcher for the pipeline editor (and beyond) we need a way to fetch a list of active branches on a project in GraphQL.

### Proposal

Create a GraphQL resolver that should work with the following query (or similar):

```graphql
query getAvailableBranches {
  project(fullPath: "gitlab-org/gitlab") {
    branches {
      nodes{
        id
        title
      }
    }
  }
}
```

### Further details

Please see the associated [epic](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/5393) for more details.

### Availability & Testing

title: Group Maintainers are able to use the Group CI/CD Variables API
description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "bug" label:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=regression
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=bug

and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.
--->

### Summary

Group Maintainers are able to use the [Group CI/CD Variables API](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/group_level_variables.html). According to our [permissions model](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/permissions.html#group-members-permissions), this action should be limited to Group Owners. Thus is a critical elevation of user permissions.

### Steps to reproduce

<!-- Describe how one can reproduce the issue - this is very important. Please use an ordered list. -->

`curl --request POST --header "PRIVATE-TOKEN: $GROUP_MAINTAINER_TOKEN" "https://gitlab.com/api/v4/groups/$GROUP_ID/variables" --form "key=maintainertest" --form "value=test"`


### What is the current *bug* behavior?

Group Maintainers are able to manage Group-level CI/CD variables using the [API](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/group_level_variables.html).

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

Only Group Owners should be able to manage Group-level CI/CD variables.

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

```
curl --request POST --header "PRIVATE-TOKEN: $GROUP_MAINTAINER_TOKEN" "https://gitlab.com/api/v4/groups/$GROUP_ID/variables" --form "key=maintainertest" --form "value=test"
{"variable_type":"env_var","key":"maintainertest","value":"test","protected":false,"masked":false}%
```

expected

```
curl --request POST --header "PRIVATE-TOKEN: $GROUP_MAINTAINER_TOKEN" "https://gitlab.com/api/v4/groups/$GROUP_ID/variables" --form "key=maintainertest" --form "value=test"
{"message":"403 Forbidden"}
```

### Output of checks

This bug happens on GitLab.com

title: Allow users to work off the non-default branch in the pipeline editor
description:
### Problem to solve 

As an iterative step towards &5393 we should add the ability to edit pipeline configs on the non-default branch.
There will be no UI to take us here for this step so we'll need to use the URL to identify which branch we're editing.

### Proposal

In the single file editor the URI is:

`https://[instance].com/[group]/[project]/-/blob/[branch-name]/[filename]`

Using that format, we may be able to use the following URI

`https://[instance].com/[group]/[project]/-/ci/blob/[branch-name]/editor`

However, rails is weird and URIs are weirder so maybe it's easier to use a query string for now.

`https://[instance].com/[group]/[project]/-/ci/editor?branch_name=[branch-name]`

Whichever approach we take, we should use that branch name to populate the editor with the CI config on that particular branch.

We'll also need to update the target branch in the commit form to be the branch we're currently on.

### Further details

On it's own, this feature isn't all that useful.
However, as a first step on the linked epic, it opens a lot of doors.

### Documentation

As this feature isn't discoverable, and is simply a first step, I don't see this needing Documentation at this stage.

### Availability & Testing

<!-- This section needs to be retained and filled in during the workflow planning breakdown phase of this feature proposal, if not earlier.

What risks does this change pose to our availability? How might it affect the quality of the product? What additional test coverage or changes to tests will be needed? Will it require cross-browser testing?

Please list the test areas (unit, integration and end-to-end) that needs to be added or updated to ensure that this feature will work as intended. Please use the list below as guidance.
* Unit test changes
* Integration test changes
* End-to-end test change

See the test engineering planning process and reach out to your counterpart Software Engineer in Test for assistance: https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/quality/test-engineering/#test-planning -->

### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?

We should be able to:
1. Load the CI config for a branch by entering the right URL.
2. Edit the config on that branch with all the features of the editor working correctly.
3. Commit the changes to that same branch
4. Commit the changes to a new branch and open an MR with the target branch as the base.

title: Prevent DAST profiles to be modified or deleted when are referenced by active policy
description:
<!--
Implementation issues are used break-up a large piece of work into small, discrete tasks that can
move independently through the build workflow steps. They're typically used to populate a Feature
Epic. Once created, an implementation issue is usually refined in order to populate and review the
implementation plan and weight.
Example workflow: https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/development/threat-management/planning/diagram.html#plan
-->

## Why are we doing this work
<!--
A brief explanation of the why, not the what or how. Assume the reader doesn't know the
background and won't have time to dig-up information from comment threads.
-->

As a part of the related Epic it is required to prohibit users from being able to edit or delete any Scan Profiles or Site Profiles that are referenced by an active policy. This issue addresses that requirement.


## Non-functional requirements
<!--
Add details for required items and delete others.
-->

- [x] Documentation:
  
  Add information note to https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/application_security/dast/#site-profile and https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/application_security/dast/#scanner-profile with explanation that these profiles cannot be modified/deleted if they are referenced by Security Policy
- [x] Feature flag: when feature flag is disabled we should not perform this check,
- [-] Performance:
- [x] Testing:
  - [ ] Test you can create/modify/delete DAST Site Profile and DAST Scanner Profile that is not referenced by Security Policy
  - [ ] Test you can create DAST Site Profile and DAST Scanner Profile that is referenced by Security Policy if it was not created before,
  - [ ] Test you cannot modify/delete DAST Site Profile and DAST Scanner Profile that is referenced by Security Policy


## Implementation plan
<!--
Steps and the parts of the code that will need to get updated. The plan can also
call-out responsibilities for other team members or teams.
-->

- [x] ~backend extract logic responsible for deletion in `Mutations::DastSiteProfiles::Delete` to separate service: `DastSiteProfiles::DestroyService`,
- [x] ~backend extend `Dast::Profiles::UpdateService`, `Dast::Profiles::DestroyService`, `::DastSiteProfiles::UpdateService`, `::DastSiteProfiles::DestroyService` with logic to check if it is referenced by policy (proposed logic to do the check -> it is recommended to first extend `Security::OrchestrationPolicyConfiguration` with methods `dast_profile_referenced?(profile_name)` and `dast_site_profile_referenced?(profile_name)` to check if profile with given name was referenced by any policy and then use that logic like below):

```ruby
def referenced_by_policy?
  return false unless feature_enabled?(:security_orchestration_policy_configuration)
  return false unless profile.project.security_orchestration_policy_configuration

  profile.project.security_orchestration_policy_configuration.active_policies.any? do |policy|
    policy[:actions].any? { |action| action[:site_profile] == profile.name }
  end
end
```
- [x] ~backend Extend `Types::DastSiteProfileType` and `Types::DastScannerProfileType` with field `referencedInPolicies` as array of strings with policies names where selected profile is referenced

## Expectations

### What are we expecting to happen?

- We start to [update](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/a9f92ed92dfffa2d72e2c4ac67f4c778d4c60a3c/lib/api/commit_statuses.rb#L105) older commit-statuses if it is tried to be retried via [API](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/commits.html#post-the-build-status-to-a-commit).
- We start to [update](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/a9f92ed92dfffa2d72e2c4ac67f4c778d4c60a3c/app/services/projects/update_pages_service.rb#L36) older commit-statuses if it is a `pages:deploy` job and retried.

### What might happen if this goes wrong?

`UPDATE` query may fail at worst... Or may take long...

### What can we monitor to detect problems with this?

- We should not see an increase of "500" response => https://log.gprd.gitlab.net/goto/c972a59852d5e12ce10593159a071acf
- We should not see an increase of response time average => https://log.gprd.gitlab.net/goto/ab081ea275df6277cd7a475ffae03b1f
- We should not see an increase of "fail" job status => https://log.gprd.gitlab.net/goto/cecdc414bf68ddb9176d617da04c0f18
- We should not see an increase of duration average => https://log.gprd.gitlab.net/goto/ab0e13ef0f390bb614dd1a6117cb064c

## Beta groups/projects

If applicable, any groups/projects that are happy to have this feature turned on early. Some organizations may wish to test big changes they are interested in with a small subset of users ahead of time for example.

- `gitlab-org/gitlab` project
- `gitlab-org`/`gitlab-com` groups
- ...

## Roll Out Steps

- [x] Enable on staging (`/chatops run feature set feature_name true --staging`)
- [ ] Test on staging
- [ ] Ensure that documentation has been updated
- [x] Enable on GitLab.com for individual groups/projects listed above and verify behaviour  (`/chatops run feature set --project=gitlab-org/gitlab feature_name true`)
- [x] Coordinate a time to enable the flag with the SRE oncall and release managers
  - In `#production` mention `@sre-oncall` and `@release-managers`. Once an SRE on call and Release Manager on call confirm, you can proceed with the rollout
- [ ] Announce on the issue an estimated time this will be enabled on GitLab.com
- [x] Enable on GitLab.com by running chatops command in `#production` (`/chatops run feature set feature_name true`)
- [ ] Cross post chatops Slack command to `#support_gitlab-com` ([more guidance when this is necessary in the dev docs](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#where-to-run-commands)) and in your team channel
- [ ] Announce on the issue that the flag has been enabled
- [ ] Remove feature flag and add changelog entry. Ensure that the feature flag definition YAML file has been removed in the **same MR** that is removing the feature flag from the code
- [ ] After the flag removal is deployed, [clean up the feature flag](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up) by running chatops command in `#production` channel

## Rollback Steps

- [ ] This feature can be disabled by running the following Chatops command:

```

## Rollout Steps

### Rollout on non-production environments

- [ ] Ensure that the feature MRs have been deployed to non-production environments.
    - [ ] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit-of-your-feature>`
- [x] Enable the feature globally on non-production environments.
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set ci_remove_update_retried_from_process_pipeline true --dev`
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set ci_remove_update_retried_from_process_pipeline true --staging`
- [x] Verify that the feature works as expected. Posting the QA result in this issue is preferable.

### Preparation before production rollout

- [ ] Ensure that the feature MRs have been deployed to both production and canary.
    - [ ] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit-of-your-feature>`
- [ ] Check if the feature flag change needs to be accompanied with a
  [change management issue](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/infrastructure/change-management/#feature-flags-and-the-change-management-process).
  Cross link the issue here if it does.
- [ ] Ensure that you or a representative in development can be available for at least 2 hours after feature flag updates in production.
  If a different developer will be covering, or an exception is needed, please inform the oncall SRE by using the `@sre-oncall` Slack alias.
- [ ] Ensure that documentation has been updated ([More info](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/documentation/feature_flags.html#features-that-became-enabled-by-default)).
- [ ] Announce on [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) an estimated time this will be enabled on GitLab.com.
- [ ] If the feature might impact the user experience, notify `#support_gitlab-com` and your team channel ([more guidance when this is necessary in the dev docs](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#communicate-the-change)).

### Global rollout on production

All `/chatops` commands that target production should be done in the `#production` slack channel for visibility.

- [x] Confirm the feature flag is enabled on `staging` without incident
- [ ] Roll out the feature to targeted testing projects/groups first
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set --project=gitlab-org/gitlab ci_remove_update_retried_from_process_pipeline true`
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set --project=gitlab-org/gitlab-foss ci_remove_update_retried_from_process_pipeline true`
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set --project=gitlab-com/www-gitlab-com ci_remove_update_retried_from_process_pipeline true`

- [ ] [Incrementally roll out](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#process) the feature.
  - If the feature flag in code has [an actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), perform **actor-based** rollout.
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set ci_remove_update_retried_from_process_pipeline <rollout-percentage> --actors`
  - If the feature flag in code does **NOT** have [an actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), perform time-based rollout (**random** rollout).
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set ci_remove_update_retried_from_process_pipeline <rollout-percentage>`
- [ ] Verify the change has the desired outcome with the limited rollout before enabling the feature globally on production.
- [x] Enable the feature globally on production environment. `/chatops run feature set ci_remove_update_retried_from_process_pipeline true`
- [ ] Announce on [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) that the feature has been globally enabled.
- [ ] Wait for [at least one day for the verification term](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release).

### (Optional) Release the feature with the feature flag

If you're still unsure whether the feature is [deemed stable](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release)
but want to release it in the current milestone, you can change the default state of the feature flag to be enabled.
To do so, follow these steps:

- [ ] Create a merge request with the following changes. Ask for review and merge it.
    - [ ] Set the `default_enabled` attribute in [the feature flag definition](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-flag-definition-and-validation) to `true`.
    - [ ] Create [a changelog entry](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#changelog).
- [ ] Ensure that the default-enabling MR has been deployed to both production and canary.
      If the merge request was deployed before [the code cutoff](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/releases/#self-managed-releases-1),
      the feature can be officially announced in a release blog post.
    - [ ] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit-of-default-enabling-mr>`
- [ ] Close [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) to indicate the feature will be released in the current milestone.
- [ ] Set the next milestone to this rollout issue for scheduling [the flag removal](#release-the-feature).
- [ ] (Optional) You can create a separate issue for scheduling the steps below to [Release the feature](#release-the-feature).
    - [ ] Set the title to "[Feature flag] Cleanup `ci_remove_update_retried_from_process_pipeline`".
    - [ ] Execute the `/copy_metadata <this-rollout-issue-link>` quick action to copy the labels from this rollout issue.
    - [ ] Link this rollout issue as a related issue.
    - [ ] Close this rollout issue.

**WARNING:** This approach has the downside that it makes it difficult for us to
[clean up](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up) the flag.
For example, on-premise users could disable the feature on their GitLab instance. But when you
remove the flag at some point, they suddenly see the feature as enabled and they can't roll it back
to the previous behavior. To avoid this potential breaking change, use this approach only for urgent
matters.

### Release the feature

After the feature has been [deemed stable](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release),
the [clean up](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up)
should be done as soon as possible to permanently enable the feature and reduce complexity in the
codebase.

<!-- The checklist here is to help stakeholders keep track of the feature flag status -->
- [ ] Create a merge request to remove `ci_remove_update_retried_from_process_pipeline` feature flag. Ask for review and merge it.
    - [ ] Remove all references to the feature flag from the codebase.
    - [ ] Remove the YAML definitions for the feature from the repository.
    - [ ] Create [a changelog entry](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#changelog).
- [ ] Ensure that the cleanup MR has been deployed to both production and canary.

      the feature can be officially announced in a release blog post.

- [ ] Close [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) to indicate the feature will be released in the current milestone.
- [x] Clean up the feature flag from all environments by running these chatops command in `#production` channel:
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature delete ci_remove_update_retried_from_process_pipeline --dev`
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature delete ci_remove_update_retried_from_process_pipeline --staging`
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature delete ci_remove_update_retried_from_process_pipeline`
- [x] Close this rollout issue.

title: Error handling in DependencyProxy::FindOrCreateManifestService
description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "bug" label:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=regression
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=bug

and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.
--->

### Summary

The `DependencyProxy::PullManifestService` can [yield](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/a3a4846b51d81323ba875dba4050151dcc1d9099/app/services/dependency_proxy/pull_manifest_service.rb#L29) an error response.

The problem is that the caller is not [expecting](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/a3a4846b51d81323ba875dba4050151dcc1d9099/app/services/dependency_proxy/find_or_create_manifest_service.rb#L32-36) such yield.

As such, the `file` key will be accessed and we will [try](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/a3a4846b51d81323ba875dba4050151dcc1d9099/app/services/dependency_proxy/find_or_create_manifest_service.rb#L35) to get the `#size` of it. When this happens, an `undefined method 'size' for nil:NilClass` will greet us.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Pull a manifest through the dependency proxy that the get response is not a [success](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/a3a4846b51d81323ba875dba4050151dcc1d9099/app/services/dependency_proxy/pull_manifest_service.rb#L16).

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

Server error with `undefined method 'size' for nil:NilClass`

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

We probably need to return the same error that happened with the get request.

### Possible fixes

Handle the error result [here](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/a3a4846b51d81323ba875dba4050151dcc1d9099/app/services/dependency_proxy/find_or_create_manifest_service.rb#L31):

```ruby
DependencyProxy::PullManifestService.new(@image, @tag, @token).execute_with_manifest do |new_manifest|
  if new_manifest[:status] == :success
    @manifest.update!(
      digest: new_manifest[:digest],
      file: new_manifest[:file],
      size: new_manifest[:file].size
    )
  elsif new_manifest[:status] == :error
    # handle the error here.
  end
end
```

title: DB level traversal_ids and updates
description:
> :warning: :warning: :warning: This issue is exploratory and should not be considered final. :warning: :warning: :warning: 

We can improve performance of `Namespace#traversal_ids` by pushing initialization and updates to the database layer.

I have a proposal for two improvements to `traversal_ids`. These improvements effectively obsolete work completed in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/52854 which utilize feature flags by moving functionality from Ruby to SQL.

# Initialize `traversal_ids` value

The value should be:

```ruby
# Translate this to a SQL function
traversal_ids = (parent&.traversal_ids || []) + [currval('namespaces_id_seq')])
```

This would be implemented as a SQL function and enforced through a trigger(s).

Maybe this work makes the `traversal_ids` a read only attribute in Ruby land.

# Update traversal_ids

An update to a namespaces' parent_id will have to update its `traversal_ids` and also that of its descendants `traversal_ids`. We can translate `TraversalHierarchy#sync_traversal_ids!` from Ruby to SQL to update `traversal_ids` from within the DB layer and avoid any problems caused by going around the existing Ruby code, such as with batch updates.

Implement through a column update trigger.

---

Some previous work has been saved in a branch at https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/tree/300377-traversal-ids-column-sync-with-constraints

title: Protected  Tags Bypass During Pipeline Mirroring
description:
**[HackerOne report #1097232](https://hackerone.com/reports/1097232)** by `vaib25vicky` on 2021-02-06, assigned to @rchan-gitlab:

[Report](#report) | [Attachments](#attachments) | [How To Reproduce](#how-to-reproduce)

## Report

#####  Summary

Protected tags are not validated during `pull` mirroring which results into protected tags rules bypass

#####  Steps to reproduce

* Create a public project `projA` and choose initialize with `Readme.md` at time of creation  
* Create another public project `projB` but keep this empty and don't choose initialize with `Readme.md` at time of creation  
* Define pull mirror in `projB` which will pull repository from `projA`  
 
`https://gitlab.com/<owner>/<project>/-/settings/repository#js-push-remote-settings`

![prot2.png](https://h1.sec.gitlab.net/a/c9b527b4-88e4-48c1-b3ba-9d0f2629ae14/prot2.png)

*  After successful pull,  go to `projB` settings>repository>protected_tags   
 and define rule such as 

Tags: test*  
Allowed to create: None

![prot1.png](https://h1.sec.gitlab.net/a/3f489b02-17f9-4453-a951-51636df13728/prot1.png)

* Now, tags such as `test123`, `testabc` failed because protected tags rule don't allow creating tags with rules `test*`    
* Go to `projA` create a tag such as `test123`  
* You can either wait for 5 minutes for auto pull  or can manually pull by going over `projB ` /-/settings/repository#js-push-remote-settings  
* After success, `test123` will be created in the `projB` and thus bypass the previously defined protected tags rule 


#####  What is the current *bug* behavior?

Protected tags are not validated during `pull` mirroring which results into protected tags rules bypass. In push mirror, protected tags are validated but not in pull mirror.

#####  What is the expected *correct* behavior?

Just like push mirror validating protected tags rules,  the pull mirroring should also validate the protected tags.


#####  Output of checks

This bug happens on GitLab.com

####  Impact

Protected tags are not validated during `pull` mirroring which results into protected tags rules bypass

## Attachments

**Warning:** Attachments received through HackerOne, please exercise caution!

* [prot1.png](https://h1.sec.gitlab.net/a/3f489b02-17f9-4453-a951-51636df13728/prot1.png)
* [prot2.png](https://h1.sec.gitlab.net/a/c9b527b4-88e4-48c1-b3ba-9d0f2629ae14/prot2.png)

## How To Reproduce

Please add [reproducibility information] to this section:

1.
1.

title: Support for vulnerability-allowlist.yml
description:
<!--
Implementation issues are used break-up a large piece of work into small, discrete tasks that can
move independently through the build workflow steps. They're typically used to populate a Feature
Epic. Once created, an implementation issue is usually refined in order to populate and review the
implementation plan and weight.
Example workflow: https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/development/threat-management/planning/diagram.html#plan
-->

## Why are we doing this work
<!--
A brief explanation of the why, not the what or how. Assume the reader doesn't know the
background and won't have time to dig-up information from comment threads.
-->

The existing analyzer, klar, supports [vulnerability allowlisting](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/application_security/container_scanning/#vulnerability-allowlisting). We need the new ruby-based analyzer to support the same feature.


## Relevant links
<!--
Information that the developer might need to refer to when implementing the issue.

- [Design Issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/<id>)
  - [Design 1](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/<id>/designs/<image>.png)
  - [Design 2](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/<id>/designs/<image>.png)
- [Similar implementation](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/<id>)
-->


## Non-functional requirements
<!--
Add details for required items and delete others.
-->

- [ ] Documentation:
- [ ] Feature flag:
- [ ] Performance:
- [ ] Testing: scan the same vulnerable image with both analyzers and the same allow list. The results must be the same for the allowed findings.


## Implementation plan
<!--
Steps and the parts of the code that will need to get updated. The plan can also
call-out responsibilities for other team members or teams.
-->

- [x] Add support to allow list based on `generalallowlist` which has the following format:
```
generalallowlist:
  <CVE-NUMBER>: <BINARY/SERVICE-NAME>
  ...
```

- [x] Add support to allow list scoped to an image based on the following format:
```
images:
 <REGISTRY/IMAGE_NAME>:
   <CVE-NUMBER>: <BINARY/SERVICE-NAME> 
   ...
 ...
```

- [x] Add support to allow list scoped to an image based (with SHA256) on the following format:
```
images:
 <REGISTRY/IMAGE_NAME>@sha256:<SHA256>:
   <CVE-NUMBER>: <BINARY/SERVICE-NAME> 
   ...
 ...
```

~"group::" ~"Category:" ~"GitLab Ultimate"
-->

Other settings you might want to include when creating the issue.

-->

title: Standardize backend tracking to use a single method
description:
Based on this discussion: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/299132#note_507458909

We would like to have only one way to track backend events. Events should be sent by calling `Gitlab::Tracking.event`.

Currently, there are two helpers that also exist, which do not seem to provide much additional value.

1. Controller concern: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/lib/gitlab/tracking.rb#L7
1. API helper: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/lib/api/helpers.rb#L542

These can be removed in favour of the standard call to `Gitlab::Tracking.event`.

description:
### Overview

title: Spike: Investigate and plan refactoring of Blob view into Vue app
description:
## Summary

<!--
Please briefly describe what part of the code base needs to be refactored.
-->

There's an opportunity to refactor the current blob view (https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/README.md) into Vue.

The idea is that we'll be able to navigate throughout the repository using the file browser and when clicking on a filename instead of being brought to the blob HAML page, we'd pull the blob content and render the viewer in Vue.

This allows for a quicker jump from the file list to the rendered file. Also allows for a quicker return to the file tree, in case user wants to go back. 

## Improvements

<!--
Explain the benefits of refactoring this code.
See also https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/values/index.html#say-why-not-just-what
-->

* Quick jump from file list to file content
* Quick jump back from file content to file list
* Pre-fetching the blob content as soon as obvious user will select it (mouse over, mouse down...)
* Initially, rewriting current set of viewers (https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/tree/master/app/views/projects/blob/viewers) then more interactive viewers can be added in the future.


## Risks

<!--
Please list features that can break because of this refactoring and how you intend to solve that.
-->

It is paramount that this change **does not affect SEO negatively**

## Involved components

<!--
List files or directories that will be changed by the refactoring.
-->

* `app/assets/javascripts/repository/*`
* Old code to be disabled/removed: app/views/projects/blob/_blob.html.haml (and associated ruby code)

## Optional: Intended side effects

<!--
If the refactoring involves changes apart from the main improvements (such as a better UI), list them here.
It may be a good idea to create separate issues and link them here.
-->


## Optional: Missing test coverage

<!--
If you are aware of tests that need to be written or adjusted apart from unit tests for the changed components,
please list them here.
-->

<!--
Please select the appropriate label from the following:
    ~"feature::addition"
    ~"feature::maintenance"
    ~"tooling::pipelines"
    ~"tooling::workflow"
-->

## Deliverables

* Turn https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/320925 into an epic
* Open issues for each step
* Add issues to that epic

title: Project template vs "Security & Compliance" feature
description:
Hi @kassio :wave:

I've faced a problem related to this change while working on something. Recently we've introduced a new feature group called "Security & Compliance" which works as a roof feature for security and compliance-related features. It's there to make it easier to switch off all the related features by using the project visibility settings. All the "Security & Compliance" related features require by default the developer access therefore the default feature setting has been set as `PRIVATE`. But because of the change here, it is now breaking some tests as now we require users to have access to private features to use the template.

I wanted to ask you as you've authored on this change; can't we just check the feature access while exporting the data of related features? If there are other problems with that approach, I will introduce a change like the following one as we are not exporting "Security & Compliance" related data yet.

```diff
diff --git a/app/models/project_feature.rb b/app/models/project_feature.rb
index 0326ae037a4..3f86a1ce979 100644
--- a/app/models/project_feature.rb
+++ b/app/models/project_feature.rb
@@ -4,6 +4,7 @@ class ProjectFeature < ApplicationRecord
   include Featurable

   FEATURES = %i(issues forking merge_requests wiki snippets builds repository pages metrics_dashboard analytics operations security_and_compliance).freeze
+  EXPORTABLE_FEATURES = (FEATURES - [:security_and_compliance]).freeze

   set_available_features(FEATURES)

diff --git a/ee/app/finders/custom_project_templates_finder.rb b/ee/app/finders/custom_project_templates_finder.rb
index ff37527d248..7c1d48421d8 100644
--- a/ee/app/finders/custom_project_templates_finder.rb
+++ b/ee/app/finders/custom_project_templates_finder.rb
@@ -14,7 +14,7 @@ def initialize(current_user:, search: nil, subgroup_id: nil, project_id: nil)
   def execute
     scope = super

-    ::ProjectFeature::FEATURES.reduce(scope) do |scope, feature|
+    ::ProjectFeature::EXPORTABLE_FEATURES.reduce(scope) do |scope, feature|
       scope.with_feature_access_level(feature, ::ProjectFeature::DISABLED)
         .or(scope.with_feature_available_for_user(feature, current_user))
     end
```

How do you feel about the above change?

Also, `ProjectFeature::FEATURES` is not the only place we set the features, there is also the `EE::ProjectFeature::FEATURES`.

From: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/commit/f0103eafb3c456d7842a37311e818a9ac25d7885#note_508175169
